### Definitions

In vector-matrix notation we have, for some set of coefficients $\phi_{\bullet, \bullet}$, 

$$
\begin{align} 
  z_{\bullet, 1} &= \phi_{1, 1} \; \dot{f}_\bullet \; + \; \phi_{2, 1} \; \dot{s}_\bullet \\ 
  z_{\bullet, 2} &= \phi_{1, 2} \; \dot{f}_\bullet \; + \; \phi_{2, 2} \; \dot{s}_\bullet \\ \\ 
  &\text{so that} \\ \\ 
  \begin{pmatrix}
    z_{\bullet, 1} & z_{\bullet, 2}
  \end{pmatrix}
   &= 
  \begin{pmatrix}
    \dot{f}_\bullet & \dot{s}_\bullet
  \end{pmatrix} \; 
  \begin{pmatrix}
    \phi_{1, 1} & \phi_{1, 2} \\
    \phi_{2, 1} & \phi_{2, 2} 
  \end{pmatrix} \\ 
  &= 
  \begin{pmatrix}
    \dot{f}_\bullet & \dot{s}_\bullet
  \end{pmatrix} \; 
  \begin{pmatrix}
    \phi_{\bullet, 1} & \phi_{\bullet, 2}
  \end{pmatrix}
\end{align} 
$$ {#eq-fs-pca-1}

It turns out that the coefficient vectors, $(\phi_{\bullet, 1}, \phi_{\bullet, 2})$ are eigen-vectors of the sample covariance matrix.

$$
\begin{align} 
  &
  \left \{ 
  \frac{1}{n - 1} \; 
  \begin{pmatrix}
    \dot{f}_\bullet^\top \\
    \dot{s}_\bullet^\top 
  \end{pmatrix} \; 
  \begin{pmatrix}
    \dot{f}_\bullet & \dot{s}_\bullet
  \end{pmatrix}
  \right \} \; 
  \begin{pmatrix}
    \phi_{\bullet, 1} & \phi_{\bullet, 2}
  \end{pmatrix} \\ \\ 
  &= 
  \begin{pmatrix}
    \phi_{\bullet, 1} & \phi_{\bullet, 2}
  \end{pmatrix} \; 
  \begin{pmatrix}
    \sigma_1^2 & 0 \\
    0 & \sigma_2^2 
  \end{pmatrix} 
\end{align} 
$$ {#eq-fs-pca-2}

Each of the coefficient vectors, $(\phi_{\bullet, 1}, \phi_{\bullet, 2})$ is a unit vector, and the two vectors are orthogonal to one another.  That is, the matrix $(\phi_{\bullet, 1}, \phi_{\bullet, 2})$ is an orthonormal matrix.  Multiplying @eq-fs-pca-2 on the right by the transpose of $(\phi_{\bullet, 1}, \phi_{\bullet, 2})$, we obtain an eigen-decomposition (or polar decompositon) of the sample covariance matrix.

$$
\begin{align} 
  &
  \frac{1}{n - 1} \; 
  \begin{pmatrix}
    \dot{f}_\bullet^\top \\
    \dot{s}_\bullet^\top 
  \end{pmatrix} \; 
  \begin{pmatrix}
    \dot{f}_\bullet & \dot{s}_\bullet
  \end{pmatrix} \\ \\ 
  &= 
  \begin{pmatrix}
    \phi_{\bullet, 1} & \phi_{\bullet, 2}
  \end{pmatrix} \; 
  \begin{pmatrix}
    \sigma_1^2 & 0 \\
    0 & \sigma_2^2 
  \end{pmatrix} \; 
  \begin{pmatrix}
    \phi_{\bullet, 1}^\top \\ 
    \phi_{\bullet, 2}^\top
  \end{pmatrix}
\end{align} 
$$ {#eq-fs-pca-3}

The matrix of coefficients $(\phi_{\bullet, 1}, \phi_{\bullet, 2})$ takes the form of a 2D rotation matrix.

$$
\begin{align} 
  \begin{pmatrix}
    \phi_{1, 1} & \phi_{1, 2} \\
    \phi_{2, 1} & \phi_{2, 2} 
  \end{pmatrix} 
  &= 
  \begin{pmatrix}
    \cos{\theta} & - \sin{\theta} \\
    \sin{\theta} & \cos{\theta} 
  \end{pmatrix} 
\end{align} 
$$ {#eq-fs-rot-mat}
